content.description: Good hard route. Distinct crux. Ignore the guidebook suggestion that the upper left corner is off. Same grade and much more pleasant with it on.
content.protection: TR, or some cams in the undercling, then run it out.
content.location: Middle of Poison Ivy Wall, face left of Ramses II with obvious undercling.

content.description: Classic Devils Lake small edges.  A full value route, where its hard to get off the ground, hard to top out, and there's an even harder crux somewhere in the middle.
content.location: On the east end of Poison Ivy Wall, the wall of moderates.  Between "Portrait Corner" and "Deception".

content.description: A burly little crack.  To do this with grace requires keeping your body away from the crack, but the brief fist/off-width moves will try to suck you in.  Overhangs a little at the top for full value.
content.protection: You'll only need a couple of pieces, but they could both be wide.  You'll want a couple of medium pieces at the top for the belay anchor, too.
content.location: Just to the right of the Lost Arrow, in the center of the East-facing wall.

content.description: Like Ramses II, a burly little crack with an awkward move and an overhang at the top.
content.location: Just to the right of Ramses II

content.description: Start at the base of the v-shaped groove.  Climb the groove and move right to the block, or stay right and climb directly to the block.  Shift out to the corner, and use your best technique to reach up and left.  Reminiscent of "Ostentation."  Continue up.
content.location: Past Lost Arrow and Ramses heading east is the longest stretch of PI Wall.  Toward the left-hand end of this wall is a v-shaped groove or gully.  Portrait Corner starts here.

content.description: Step up to flaring out notch. Step up to good hand hold. Follow cracks and locks to the top. Fun climb overall.Â
content.protection: Standard stoppers/rack, tree at top for anchor.
content.location: This is the crack system to right of the Deception and #12 in Swartling's.

content.description: Start on the outer right face, use small ledges (like "Aku Aku") and the right arete.  The crux is at the bottom.
content.location: The outer right facet of the Spire.

content.description:
Two moves.  Begin out of the notch between PI Wall and the Spire (okay, you have to scramble this far).  The first move is the crux.  The guidebook calls this move 5.6, but the difficulty depends on your inseam.  I'd say 5.6-5.8. 

  Don't forget to stand up on top.
content.protection: One or two small nuts, tricams, or small cams.  A 20+ ft piece of webbing to set a TR.
content.location: At the left end of Poison Ivy Wall, you pass it as you come into this area.

climbs.name: Lamb & Eggs
climbs.fa: First Lead Schroeder and Knower 3/24/16 or Old School

content.description:
Unlisted in the most recent edition of Swartling and Mayer this chimney/gully seemed like an obvious natural line and was most likely ascended in the days before recorded history and then wisely forgotten. 

  Easier, low-angle climbing with excellent rests leads to a steeper crux  near the top. That crux involves a disconcerting reach-and-step to the right to attain the final slab that guards the route's finish.  

  A muddy, horizontal hand jam between a large boulder and the dirt beneath makes the final move to the belay more comfortable.
content.protection: A set of stoppers and a set of cams (.4-4 C4).
content.location: In the middle of Poison Ivy Wall. Just left of Portrait Corner.

climbs.name: Ladybug Layback
climbs.fa: FRA:  Aaron Smith's friends, sometime before summer 2007

content.description: Left-slanting crack in a prow of rock
content.location: On the left end of PI Wall, near the access routes from above and below.  Just west of the Lost Arrow.

content.description: Wide, left-leaning crack.   #11 in the devils lake guide book 3rd edition. page 85
content.protection: You can top rope the route with great protection at top or lead all with hand size or bigger gear.
content.location: Far right side of Poison Ivy Wall. The left most crack on the far right wall.

climbs.name: Creeping Ivy
climbs.fa: Mason Mueller, Nick Mueller, Jon Mueller

content.description: The only 5.8 move is the start. Start with two hands on the lower most hold. Into a bouldery start. Gain the flat ledge after cruxy start. Dont use left or right side on face.    5.5. Left side variation.
content.protection: Top rope with two big trees at top.
content.location: Between #1 and #2 in the 3rd edition devils lake guide book page 84. Only climb face to the right of lost arrow.

pathTokens: East Bluff 03 - West of the Quarry

content.description: Part of the West Terrace group of rocks, the next level below Bird-Foot Buttress, and the level above White Wall.  Poison Ivy Wall might be called the "Wall of Moderates" as there are easily ten routes in the 5.6-5.8 range here.    The two test pieces, "Under the Bottle" and "Say Cheese" are worth a look if you are in the area for "American Dream Roof."  Ironically, we found a little virginia creeper but no poison ivy here.
